creditline: Gift of Tamara and Michael Root
description: trompe l'oeil sculpture in the form of a stacked 3 teacups and 3 demitasse cups in a cigar box on top of a yellow book titled "Imagined Wisconsin" on spine; cups are blue and white Chinese style decorations; cigar box has red and yellow design with applied labels "Robert Burns Segars" and "Robert Hudson, Inc. / Fine American Art"
medium: Porcelain, cast, glazed with transfer decals
text:
In the mid-1960s, Shaw was studying painting and sculpture at the University of California, Davis, when he began moving away from abstraction in his ceramic work and toward replication. 

Through grant funding, he developed decals that allowed him to create amazing tromp l'oeil (literally, “fool the eye”) pieces from porcelain, using it as a 3-D blank canvas. Canton Collection uses the English name for Guangzhou, an important port for the Chinese blue-and-white porcelain trade in the 1700s. The reference connects faux blue-and-white cups and a jar—all made from porcelain—with a grounding Midwestern literary reference.
title: Canton Collection
